posts.name: James
posts.cooked:
Hello from 564! We are doing some work on the robot at a team members house, and ran into an issue. While trying to put an 18 gauge wire into the PDH , we discovered that one of the levers were broken and are unable to get the wire into the port (Pictured Here). How can we get the wire in? We do not have a mini- PDH on hand. Follow up question - does limelight 3 plug into the 5V or 12V port of the VRM . Our head electrician said he’s pretty sure it’s 12, but figured we’d double check here. IMG_2212 1920×1440 261 KB

IMG_2212 1920×1440 261 KB

IMG_2212 1920×1440 261 KB

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff

Wiring LL3 (from their quickstart)

Hardware specs show 4.1-16V input range.

posts.name: Stewart Riley
posts.cooked: I hate to be the bearer of bad news, but for the question of how you get the wire into the broken WAGO connector the answer is…you don’t. Based on your picture, the lever of the WAGO is broken off right at the base, so there’s nothing to grab, even with a tool, to manipulate it. Without that, you’ll never get the wire in there or you’ll never be able to lock it in place (hard to tell from the picture if it was broken by opening or closing it, but either way is bad.)I haven’t opened up a PDH to find out if those can be replaced, but I wouldn’t bet on it. Our team’s first PDH had one of the main port’s WAGOs break the same way and we were never able to use that port again. Sorry again to be giving you the answer you didn’t want, but I’m afraid that there isn’t a better one.

posts.name: James
posts.cooked: This is kind of what we figured. We’re hoping we can get a mini- PDH soon and wire it to that, we were just reaching out on the off chance that there was something we hadn’t thought of.

posts.name: Mark Wasserman
posts.cooked:
Kinda shooting from the hip here…

If this was my PDH , I would disassemble it, desolder the WAGO (this is the hard part), buy a replacement from Digikey (they might only come in gray vs. red/black).  At this point, it is only legal to use in a non competition situation.

posts.name: Ryan Reed
posts.cooked:
Note on replacing the WAGOs: they can be pulled apart (its basically just a stack of them with a end cap) so if you desolder and remove them all, you can take the broken one apart and replace the lever with the lever from the new one you bought.

Desoldering all of them will be difficult as will getting them back in there when you are done. I recommend lots of solder wick and some leaded solder. Diluting the lead-free solder with leaded solder will make it easier to remove, but will be an iterative process. Solder flux will help the wick to clear out the hole to put the repaired Wagos back in.

If you keep the colors the same it should be legal under R710M.

posts.name: Mark Wasserman
posts.cooked:
Ryan_Reed:

you can take the broken one apart and replace the lever with the lever from the new one you bought.

Way better idea.

posts.name: Brett B Bonner
posts.cooked:
So as others have said, this channel can’t be used without repair.

There are a few solutions/workarounds depending on whether it, and the robot, need to be competition-legal.

REV offers a PDH repair service .  If it needs to be competition legal and you’re not confident in the team’s ability to do an “as original” DIY repair, this may be a good option for $110 plus shipping; contact REV support to confirm before you send it off to them.

Since only 1 of the 3 low-power PDH channels is damaged, you can still run the Rio and radio off the 2 remaining good ones, making those connections competition-legal.  You can then power other things (like limelights or other custom circuits) from a main PDH channel (assuming you have one available), you just need a 10A breaker or 20A breaker for it.  (Watch your wire gauge, see R622.)

If not concerned about being competition-legal, you can use a couple of Wago 221-413 (or similar) to split a low power output to run multiple things within the current rating of the fuse supplying the circuit.  For example, you could run a Limelight and radio on the same circuit quite easily; while the competition rules require the radio to have its own circuit, it isn’t drawing anywhere near the 10A limit of that circuit.  This would be perfectly functional for a development robot that doesn’t have to pass inspection.

TullE564:

does limelight 3 plug into the 5V or 12V port of the VRM

Limelight 3 accepts 4.1 to 16V, so it doesn’t have to be powered from the VRM ; it’s capable of running from unregulated robot power.  You can connect it directly to a PDH circuit or to a Mini Power Module, if you end up using one.

posts.cooked: We have tried to desolder the Wago on the PDH before and it hasnt worked. The issue being that essentially the entire board is a heat sink that absorbs the heat from the iron or gun. It may be possible with tools that we don’t have on hand though. (Note this was with the main power in Wago)

posts.name: Taegen P
posts.cooked:
bbonner:

If it needs to be competition legal and you’re not confident in the team’s ability to do an “as original” DIY repair, this may be a good option for $110 plus shipping; contact REV support to confirm before you send it off to them.

As a follow up to this, we just sent a PDH to REV for repair of a WAGO lever, although ours was the main power and not one of the little ones. They did say we would be able to purchase the lever and replace it and it would be competition legal, but we just spent the $110 to have the pros do it.

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked:
I’ll look up the series to link tomorrow morning but as I recall from looking at the datasheet: (edit - @AriMB mentioned the series below - right in the description it says “Push-In Cage Clamp”)

If the terminal is in the closed and locked position, it still should have push-to-seat capability.

As others have mentioned the terminal blocks are soldered to the PCB, this will take a lot of heat but it is certainly repairable with persistence and a little skill. I think repair is the ultimate solution.

But in a pinch you could strip the largest gauge wire that fits in that port, crimp a ferrule on the stripped end, then very, very firmly PUSH the terminal into the port where it normally seates and is closed.

You will have to overcome the spring force of the jaws but it is do-oable and is listed as one of the terminal insertion methods of the WAGO datasheet as I recall. I recall testing this out on one of ours a year and a half back just because, it takes a steady hand and a lot of force but it works for insertion!

Now the difficulty will be removal - so I recommend making it a ~8in or longer pigtail, cutting at that length then using a WAGO221 in-line lever-loc as your new temporary termination point to clip new circuits too while you decide on the best course of permanent repair or future use.

posts.cooked: We had a broken lever on a PDH this last year. If you go directly to Wago, you can order samples at no cost and they’ll ship them to you. We took the lever off a sample and students replaced it pretty easily

posts.name: Jeremiah Johnson
posts.cooked: I’ll second Wago being awesome with samples. I only needed a CAD model of some connectors and the next thing I know I have a sample pack in my mailbox and an email conversation with a rep offering to send me whatever I need for the robotics team at no charge.

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked:
As others have suggested, send your PDH to REV to be repaired properly.

Board with large plane layers that act as heatsinks make desoldering very difficult with typical soldering irons and it is likely that one can damage the circuit board. Frequently, I have seen the boards damaged because the iron was held on the joint so long in an (unsuccessful) attempt to melt the solder, the fiberglass material delaminated. The worst is if one pulls a plated hole out because the iron was not hot enough.

In the past, I have replaced the Wago and Weidmuller connectors using either the desoldering stations at work or using a high-power, high thermal mass soldering iron like the one shown below. I have also used it for desoldering difficult parts at my workplace when the regular soldering irons were not sufficient. One has to be quick to prevent damaging the board with excessive heat. I purchased mine at an antique radio swap meet but they are still made and sold.

American Beuty soldering iron 520×281 40.4 KB

American Beuty soldering iron 520×281 40.4 KB

American Beuty soldering iron 520×281 40.4 KB

posts.name: Chris Herzog
posts.cooked:
philso:

Frequently, I have seen the boards damaged because the iron was held on the joint so long in an (unsuccessful) attempt to melt the solder, the fiberglass material delaminated. The worst is if one pulls a plated hole out because the iron was not hot enough.

@philso is spot on here.  Pulling a plated hole is really bad especially on a more than 2 layer board because that can be serving as an interlayer via as well - lots of times you can bodge things back to life if you know where that buried trace resurfaces at a component but it’s bad.  The #1 cause of this is not enough heat to get all the solder melted and pulling before things have fully melted (and are still partially soldered).

My experience has been it’s better to go in with a bigger and hotter iron and get things done quickly than sit with a too small iron that is loosing temperature to a component pin or PCB trace that is acting like a heatsink.

I used to do a lot of model railroad stuff and one of my super powers there was soldering feeders onto the rail.  You typically have plastic ties with plastic “spikes” and things were easy to melt.  Some of the folks in the club would try to use their teeny irons and end up melting an inch of plastic and still not get a good solder joint.  I would use a more substantial iron running pretty hot and be in and out before the plastic knew what hit it.

When soldering, heat damage comes from a couple of things:

temperature delta - higher temps have more potential for damage

longer times - the more time you are on a part, the more time the heat has to migrate down the lead or the PCB trace or whatever

I’ve found getting in hot and getting it done helps a ton.

Something else to keep in mind is that the copper on the PCB is glued to the fiberglass substrate using a heat sensitive adhesive.  This results in the copper almost “floating” while the soldering is going on which helps prevent stresses from expansion due to heating.  Be careful not to “wipe” the trace with your soldering iron - you’ll lift it right off the board.

In the end, @philso is right - heat is your buddy and having enough thermal mass gives you enough energy to get in and get out without having every cool down as soon as you touch your part.

This takes practice - if you’ve got a mentor that might be able to supply some scrap PCBs to practice on (or look around for broken parts of the control system - every team probably has some), try them out to get your feel.  It’s a great way to refine your technique before you hit something you want to get right the first time.
